BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY Z5, 1915.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

DR. GOODNOW'S INAUGURATION

WALK-OVER FOR SOPHOMORES

LAYFIELD HAS A CHANCE TO LIVE

EDITORSHIP HAS CHANGED HANDS

New President Will Be Formally Installed
On or About May 20 at Homewood.
Occasion a "Maryland Day."

Freshmen Overwhelmed in Annual Interclass Meet, 64 to 13—Senior Relay
Victorious —Binford the Star.

Dr. Baer and Associates Performed Satisfactory Operation on the Injured
Quarterback Last Saturday.

J. Saulsbury Short Resigned Chief Position Last Week and E. M.Spieker
Was Chosen Successor.

Dr. Frank J. Goodnow will be
formally inaugurated as president
of the University on or about May
20 at Homewood. The announcement of the date and place was
first made last week to a representative of THE NEws-LETTER.
Details for the installation exercises, however, have not been completed, and two plans of procedure
are under consideration. One idea
is to have the exercises out of doors
on the lawn just west of the Mechanical and Electrical Engineering
Building. A great tent would be
pitched upon this space, and accommodations for a couple of thousand people thus made. The speakers and guests of honor will be
seated on the portico of the engineering building. It is pointed out
that the building would serve as
an excellent sounding board for the
voices of the speakers.
The other plan is to hold the exercises in machinery hall of the
engineering building. This hall is
in the form of a great L, and a
plaform erected at the angle could
be seen by nearly two thousand
persons comfortably seated in the
wings.
The occasion will have a double
significance, being not only the inauguration of the third president,
but also the formal dedication of
the Homewood Estate. The idea
of holding the exercises in the engineering building resulted from the
desire to honor the State in some
manner showing appreciation of the
assistance given in the establishment of the technical department.
At all events, the occasion will be
distinctly a Maryland affair, and it
IS said that if arrangements can
he satisfactorily completed, the exercises will be held in the building
provided by the State—the engineering building.
A large number of invitations
will be sent out, and the day' undoubtedly will be marked by the
gathering of some of the foremost
educators in the country.
Another feature will be the
formal opening of the two new
buildings at Homewood. After the
exercises the doors of the engineering building and of Gilman Hall
will be thrown open, and visitors
will be invited to inspect them. Gilman Hall is considered a "model
library building," and will undoubtedly attract a great deal of attention.
The plans, ,however, are only
tentative, but both of the ideas will
be notable for the manner in which

The annual interclass meet, held
in the cage last Saturday. was a
walk-over for the sophomores, who
piled up a score of 64 points to 13.
Wiggins and Mealy were the only
point winners for the Class of 'i8:
the former winning- the high jump
1 2 inches and taking
at 5 feet 2/
second place in the broad jump to
Binford, who won the event with
a jump of 19 feet 2Y4 inches.
Mealy surprised everybody by his
pretty performance in the mile run.
Taking a considerable lead from
the start, he maintained his advantage and finished a good 20 yards
ahead of German, '17, in the fairly
good time of 5 minutes 16 seconds.
Binford and Brooks were the
high point winners for the sophomores. By winning the broad jump,
tying for first in the quarter mile,
taking second place in the 30-yard
luirdles and running third in the
winning sophomore relay, Binford
Piled up 13 4 points. He also won
his heat in the 30-yard dash, but a
poor start in the finals lost him a
place in this event. Brooks won
the shot put at 32 feet 1 inch and
also took second place in the high
jump and the 30-yard dash, making
a total of ii points, while Jacobs
did nearly as well by winning the
30-yard dash and the 30-yard hurdles. Ten sophomores in all were
point winners.
The senior-junior relay race was
one of the most interesting events.
The senior team, composed of
Prince, Voshell, Spencer and Merrick, won by a slight margin in the
very good time of 2 minutes 30/5
seconds. Each man ran three laps
of the roo-yard track.
The meet, as a whole, was rather
uninterestjng, both because it was
so one-sided and because no exceptional times were made. Jacobs
equaled the cage record in the 30yard dash (3', seconds), but no
other records were even approached.
The soft condition of the track was
probably partly responsible for this
fact, as also the lack of keen competition in many of the events. The
track had just been made over and
had not had time to become at all
well packed.
The sophomore-freshman relay
event resulted in an overwhelming
victory for the '17 men. This was
the same team that defeated the
Georgetown freshmen last winter.
They are as yet undefeated and
hope to preserve this reputation in
the senior-junior events of the next
two years.

Bob Layfield, 'Varsity quarterback, was operated upon -last Saturday at the Delaware Hospital, Wilmington, Del. Following the operation, the announcement was made
that there is a slight chance for
his recovery, this being almost the
first hope held out by attending
physicians that the injured player
had any real chance for victory in
his brave fight to live.
The operation was performed by
Dr. William S. Baer, assisted by
fellow members of the Hopkins
staff; Drs. Ronald T. Abercrombie,
John Staige Davis and J. V. Reed.
The five physicians with Miss Bonner, a Johns Hopkins nurse, went
to Wilmington and began at noon
the operation which lasted nearly
two hours. They discovered that
by removing the bones that were
pressing down on the spinal cord,
there is a faint hone that the cord
would resume its former function.
The cord itself was found to be
slightly contused.
It was a most delicate operation,
and the physicians declare that Bob
has still a long and hard road to
travel before . ultimate recovery.
However, they say that the patient's
grit and rare good fortune may pull
him through.,
Bob insisted that the operation be
performed. His parents also appealed to Dr. Abercrombie, who last
Wednesday went to Wilmington
and had a talk with his patient.. On
his return he went into consultation
with Dr. Baer and they decided to
take the last chance to attempt to
save the life of the player.
The grit and determination displayed by Layfield since his injury
at South Bethlehem, Pa., on October 31 has alone given him a fighting chance for recovery. Since that
time he has insisted that he would
soon be well and able to play football again. In spite of sinking
spells, in one of which his temperature reached '66 -degrees, he has
fought, through several crises and
liow has a chance to live. The pin,siCians and surgeons were not optimistic about his recovery and not
until after the operation would they
say that Bob had a chance—even a
slight chance—to recover. From
the start, Bob said he would fool
them and app`arently he is Winning
out.
The operation has not relieved the
almost complete paralysis which has
extended from Bob'8 neck to his
feet from the tinie of the accident.
Pressure on the spinal cord, however, has been greatly relieved, and

A change in the editorship of

THE NEWS-LETTER took place last
week, when J. Saulsbury Short, '15,
tendered his resignation from the
Board and Edmund M. Spieker,
'16, was elected from the staff of
associate editors to the position of
editor-in-chief.
.v1 r. Short, who succeeded Alexander K. Barton as editor-in-chief,
is also editor of the Hullabaloo, and
it was because of the great amount
of time required in getting. up the
year book that he was led to give
up the weekly. His resignation was
read at the meeting of the staff on
Monday, and takes effect with this
issue. On Thursday night, at a
meeting of the entire Board, Dorsey
Richardson moved that Mr. Spieker
be elected unanimously to the position. and the motion was carried.
The new editor-in-chief is a member of the junior class and is director of the Glee Club. 1-le has been
a member of the editorial staff since
his sophomore year, and during that
time, in addition to his regular duties, has served as managing editor,
directing the publication of several
issues of the paper. He has been
one of the most active editors of
THE NEWS-LETTER, and was considered eminently qualified to direct
its affairs during the remainder of
this year and during his senior
year. He is the son of Dr. Edward
IT. Spieker, associate professor of
Greek and Latin.
At Thursday's meeting of the
Board the'question of electing several new editors was discussed, and
it was decided to choose from
among- the twenty-five candidates
five whose work stood highest in
quantity and quality. The staff,
however, wishes .it known that the
selection of the five men does not
indicate that there are no more positions to be filled.
, Later in the year several more
men are to be selected from among
the men who are already candidates
in addition to those who have recently reported themselves as interested in- the activity. The Board
will probably elect five more editors
at the end of this academic year or
next October, and invites all undergraduates to take part in the competition for the positions. Candidates should speak with Mr. Spieker
or with any other member of the
I>oard.
The Student Council says the
Crimson shall publish each year a
list of clubs with their aims. What
is the aim of the Gun Club?—Lainpoon.

The Musical Clubs will open their
season on February 3 with a concert at the Phipps Phychiatric Clinic
of the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The remainder of the concerts
which have been definitely settled
upon will be given as follows:
February 5—Western Maryland
College, Westminster, Md.
February 6—Cumberland, Md.
February 9—McCoy Hall (concert and dance).
February 16—Odd Fellows' Hall,
Baltimore.
The Instrumental Club and the
quartet will give selections at the
coming interclass debate, and several important town concerts will be
held later in thes season, with two
more trips, arrangements for which
have not yet been completed.
Much interest has been shown by
the candidates for both teams and
the work of the past week was
marked by great improvement. The
clubs are doing better work than
Hopkins musical organizations have
done in a long time, and bid fair to
have a most successful season. The
McCoy Hall concert, coming as it
does directly following the Western
Maryland trip, should be better than
usual in every particular, and other
town engagements promise to do
much toward establishing a good
reputation for the clubs.
Although they are starting out
on the season one month later than
the usual time, the leaders of the
teams are determined to make up
for lost time by doing as well as
possible at a large number of concerts, and thus to put the organization on .a firm footing for future
years. At present things look as if
the desired 'result will be accomplished.
The list of candidates for the
teams is, as it now stands, as follows:
Glee—First tenor s—Spencer,
Spieker, Hayes, Fankhanel, Aler
and Hurlow. Second tenors—Bartlett, Smith,Watson, HOughton, Nelson and Hooper. First bassos—

Uhler, Doub, Houghton, Coblentz,

DR. DUNNING A CLEVER SPEAKER

KAPPA ALPHA RE1NAUGURATED

Lecturer Under the Schouler Foundation
is Noted as Student and Wit- To
Talk on Political Theory.

Old Hopkins Fraternity Had Nine Initiates at Formal Reorganization Meeting—Three Faculty Members.

Prof. William A. Dunning, of
Columbia University, the lecturer
under the James Schouler Foundation this year, will give a series of
four addresses—the first one taking
place at 5 o'clock on Monday, January 25, in McCoy Hall.
The general subject of the whole
course will be "Early Phases of
Nineteenth Century Political Theory." This, while rather a philosophical field, is one of Dr. Dunning's specialties, and, as he has the
reputation for being one of the cleverest and most amusing talkers in
university circles, there seems little
ground for fear the lectures will be
too dry to be popular. In the words
of Dr. Schouler, under whose foundation the Columbia professor will
speak, he is "a keen investigator,
but somewhat inclining to levity in
his conclusions."
Dr. Dunning has been connected
with Columbia during his whole
teaching life and has trained many
prominent historical students. He
is author of a number of authoritative books on political philosophy
and on the Civil War and Reconstruction, the latter being his historical hobby. He is a frequent
contributor to the leading magazines, ranking high among political
commentators. From 1894 to 1903,
Dr. Dunning was managing editor
of the American Political Science
Quarterly, and in 1913 was president of the American Historical Association. He is at present Leiber
professor of history and political
philosophy in Columbia.
The lectures under the Schouler
Foundation in past years have numbered the most distinguished political students of the nation: President Lowell, of Harvard; Dr. John
Bassett Moore, of Columbia; former Assistant Secretary of State,
James Schouler; Dr. Josef Redlich,
the distinguished Austrian economist; and Dr. Charles Francis Adams, the historian of the Civil War,
who spoke here last year to audiences that filled McCoy Hall to the
doors.
The dates and subjects of Dr.
Dunning's course are as follows:
Monday, January 25—"Conservative and Reactionary Doctrine."
Tuesday, January 26— "British
Utilitarianism."
Monday, February I—"The Philosophy of Constitutionalism."
Tuesday, February —"The Philosophy of Nationalism."

Alpha Lambda Chapter, Kappa
Alpha Fraternity, resumed active
existence at Johns Hopkins with a
formal reinauguration at the Hotel
Rennert, Saturday evening, January 16. This chapter was founded
at Hopkins in 1891, but since 1910,
though remaining chartered, has
been in abeyance.
The reinduction was under the
auspices of the Baltimore Alumni
Chapter and the direction of William T. Biedler, province commander. Dr. S. Z. Ammen, one of the
founders of the order at Washington and Lee University in 1865, was
present at the initiation, as were
representatives of the Washington
alumni and of the Delaware, George
Washington, Randolph Macon,
West Virginia and Virginia chapters. The original charter was presented to the newly-organized chapter by Mr. James L. Bost, president
of the Washington Alumni Chapter,
and a Hopkins initiate.
The initiates were: Linn H. Enslow (G.), William S. Fitzgerald
(G.), J. Ernst Warrener (M.), W.
Brown Baxley, Edward E. Kaiser,
William Kendall, Jr., Thomas S.
Poole, Harold E. Scarborough and
John S. Watson. But one member
of the former chapter remains at
the University (A. L. Hammond,
'14). Kappa Alpha is represented
at the Medical School by a number of men, and in the faculty by
Professors J. B. Watson, J. H.
Latane and J. C. W. Frazer.

"TED" MERCER SPOKE AT TWO
Y. M.C. A. MEETINGS LAST WEEK

The evangelistic meetings, held
this week under the auspices of the
University Young Men's Christian
Association, were attended by very
appreciative audiences.
On Wednesday, Mr. E. C. Mercer, better known as "Ted," delivered an address pleading against
selfishness, which he pointed out
was absolutely non-Christian. Mr.
Mercer gave several instances of
the results of one's interest being
self-centered.'There were about
one hundred and twenty-five men
present. A light lunch was served
before the meeting.
After a light lunch at the Thursday noon hour, about one hundred
and ten men heard Dr. Ray Palmer
speak on "Be Sure Your Sins Will
Find You Out." It was a very
strong and forceful talk illustrated
by many interesting and actual instances.
At 5 o'clock on Thursday, Mr.
Weston G. Bruner was the speaker.
On Friday, at noon, Mr. Mercer
delivered his second and closing address of the series. In his usual
forceful manner he told his audience of about ninety why he was
a Christian. He pointed out that
many college men who had attained

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 25, 1915.

PROF. DENNISON TELLS OF
CAESAR'S BATTLES IN FRANCE

SWIMMERS MAY GET DUAL MEET
WITH PRINCETON TIGERS

"The Military Operations of
Julius Caesar in France and Belgium in Their Relation to the Present European War," was the subject of an address last Friday, delivered by Prof. Walter Dennison
of Swarthmore College, who was
annual professor at the American
School of Classical Studies in
Rome, 1908-09, and is secretary of
the Archaeological Institute of Philadelphia.
After a short introduction by
Mr. James Teakle Dennis, the new
president of the Archaeological Institute of Baltimore, Professor Dennison began by pointing out that the
battlefields of today are upon the
scene of many of the great European conflicts of the past. Upon
this same field the Celts and Teutons struggled for the fertile valley
of the Rhine twenty centuries ago.
From Caesar's first conflict with
the Helvetii in 58 B. C., Dr. Dennison traced his campaign up the
Rhine, where, near Strassburg he
met and defeated Ariovistus; thence
crossing the Vosges Mountains, he
told how Caesar overcame the Belgian host at the Aisne, and the
Nervii at Manberge.
Dr. Dennison also showed excellent views of Alesia, where in 52
B. C. the Gaulic army under Vercingetorix was shut up and starved
into submission. Here Napoleon
III erected a massive statue to the
first French national hero, and in
the nearby town of Alise is one of
the best collections of barbarian
relics now existing.
He also showed pictures of Roman
artillery and of Roman trenches discovered near this "graveyard of
the Gallic people."
By the aid of excellent illustrations Caesar's campaigns were reenacted, and his "Commentaries"
vivified in a manner which is rarely
accomplished by the average teacher.

The independent swimming team
has added another meet to its already pretentious schedule. Princeton has been practically closed for a
meet at the Baltimore Athletic Club
on Saturday evening, March 13.
While several details have yet to be
arranged in regard to this contest,
there seems to be every assurance
that it will be definitely arranged.
The Princeton Alumni Association
of Baltimore is eager to have the
Tigers appear in the city, and as the
Association's annual banquet is
scheduled to take place the same
night as the meet, hearty support
from that quarter is a certainty.
The swimmers are practicing
regularly, and are in good shape.
They will open their season next
Saturday in a practice meet with
City College in the Young Men's
Christian Association pool: Three
practices are held weekly: Tuesday
afternoon, Wednesday night and
Saturday morning.
DR. GUTTMACHER, DECEASED,
WAS A GRADUATE OF HOPKINS

The Rev. Dr. Adolf Guttmacher,
the noted Baltimore rabbi, who died
suddenly on January 17, was an
alumnus of the Johns Hopkins University.
Dr. Guttmacher received the degree of doctor of philosophy from
Hopkins in 19oo, at the same time
that Dr. William Rosenau took his
degree. His work while at this college was confined mainly to the
semitic graduate department.
Dr. Guttmacher was one of the
ablest and most esteemed rabbis of
the city. He had charge of the
Madison Avenue Temple from 1891
to 19oo, and by his conscientious
work developed that congregation
from a small body to one of more
than a thousand members.

EDITORSHIP HAS CHANGED HANDS

New President Will Be Formally Installed
On or About May 20 at Homewood.
Occasion a "Maryland Day."

Freshmen Overwhelmed in Annual Interclass Meet, 64 to 13—Senior Relay
Victorious —Binford the Star.

Dr. Baer and Associates Performed Satisfactory Operation on the Injured
Quarterback Last Saturday.

J. Saulsbury Short Resigned Chief Position Last Week and E. M.Spieker
Was Chosen Successor.

Dr. Frank J. Goodnow will be
formally inaugurated as president
of the University on or about May
20 at Homewood. The announcement of the date and place was
first made last week to a representative of THE NEws-LETTER.
Details for the installation exercises, however, have not been completed, and two plans of procedure
are under consideration. One idea
is to have the exercises out of doors
on the lawn just west of the Mechanical and Electrical Engineering
Building. A great tent would be
pitched upon this space, and accommodations for a couple of thousand people thus made. The speakers and guests of honor will be
seated on the portico of the engineering building. It is pointed out
that the building would serve as
an excellent sounding board for the
voices of the speakers.
The other plan is to hold the exercises in machinery hall of the
engineering building. This hall is
in the form of a great L, and a
plaform erected at the angle could
be seen by nearly two thousand
persons comfortably seated in the
wings.
The occasion will have a double
significance, being not only the inauguration of the third president,
but also the formal dedication of
the Homewood Estate. The idea
of holding the exercises in the engineering building resulted from the
desire to honor the State in some
manner showing appreciation of the
assistance given in the establishment of the technical department.
At all events, the occasion will be
distinctly a Maryland affair, and it
IS said that if arrangements can
he satisfactorily completed, the exercises will be held in the building
provided by the State—the engineering building.
A large number of invitations
will be sent out, and the day' undoubtedly will be marked by the
gathering of some of the foremost
educators in the country.
Another feature will be the
formal opening of the two new
buildings at Homewood. After the
exercises the doors of the engineering building and of Gilman Hall
will be thrown open, and visitors
will be invited to inspect them. Gilman Hall is considered a "model
library building," and will undoubtedly attract a great deal of attention.
The plans, ,however, are only
tentative, but both of the ideas will
be notable for the manner in which

The annual interclass meet, held
in the cage last Saturday. was a
walk-over for the sophomores, who
piled up a score of 64 points to 13.
Wiggins and Mealy were the only
point winners for the Class of 'i8:
the former winning- the high jump
1 2 inches and taking
at 5 feet 2/
second place in the broad jump to
Binford, who won the event with
a jump of 19 feet 2Y4 inches.
Mealy surprised everybody by his
pretty performance in the mile run.
Taking a considerable lead from
the start, he maintained his advantage and finished a good 20 yards
ahead of German, '17, in the fairly
good time of 5 minutes 16 seconds.
Binford and Brooks were the
high point winners for the sophomores. By winning the broad jump,
tying for first in the quarter mile,
taking second place in the 30-yard
luirdles and running third in the
winning sophomore relay, Binford
Piled up 13 4 points. He also won
his heat in the 30-yard dash, but a
poor start in the finals lost him a
place in this event. Brooks won
the shot put at 32 feet 1 inch and
also took second place in the high
jump and the 30-yard dash, making
a total of ii points, while Jacobs
did nearly as well by winning the
30-yard dash and the 30-yard hurdles. Ten sophomores in all were
point winners.
The senior-junior relay race was
one of the most interesting events.
The senior team, composed of
Prince, Voshell, Spencer and Merrick, won by a slight margin in the
very good time of 2 minutes 30/5
seconds. Each man ran three laps
of the roo-yard track.
The meet, as a whole, was rather
uninterestjng, both because it was
so one-sided and because no exceptional times were made. Jacobs
equaled the cage record in the 30yard dash (3', seconds), but no
other records were even approached.
The soft condition of the track was
probably partly responsible for this
fact, as also the lack of keen competition in many of the events. The
track had just been made over and
had not had time to become at all
well packed.
The sophomore-freshman relay
event resulted in an overwhelming
victory for the '17 men. This was
the same team that defeated the
Georgetown freshmen last winter.
They are as yet undefeated and
hope to preserve this reputation in
the senior-junior events of the next
two years.

Bob Layfield, 'Varsity quarterback, was operated upon -last Saturday at the Delaware Hospital, Wilmington, Del. Following the operation, the announcement was made
that there is a slight chance for
his recovery, this being almost the
first hope held out by attending
physicians that the injured player
had any real chance for victory in
his brave fight to live.
The operation was performed by
Dr. William S. Baer, assisted by
fellow members of the Hopkins
staff; Drs. Ronald T. Abercrombie,
John Staige Davis and J. V. Reed.
The five physicians with Miss Bonner, a Johns Hopkins nurse, went
to Wilmington and began at noon
the operation which lasted nearly
two hours. They discovered that
by removing the bones that were
pressing down on the spinal cord,
there is a faint hone that the cord
would resume its former function.
The cord itself was found to be
slightly contused.
It was a most delicate operation,
and the physicians declare that Bob
has still a long and hard road to
travel before . ultimate recovery.
However, they say that the patient's
grit and rare good fortune may pull
him through.,
Bob insisted that the operation be
performed. His parents also appealed to Dr. Abercrombie, who last
Wednesday went to Wilmington
and had a talk with his patient.. On
his return he went into consultation
with Dr. Baer and they decided to
take the last chance to attempt to
save the life of the player.
The grit and determination displayed by Layfield since his injury
at South Bethlehem, Pa., on October 31 has alone given him a fighting chance for recovery. Since that
time he has insisted that he would
soon be well and able to play football again. In spite of sinking
spells, in one of which his temperature reached '66 -degrees, he has
fought, through several crises and
liow has a chance to live. The pin,siCians and surgeons were not optimistic about his recovery and not
until after the operation would they
say that Bob had a chance—even a
slight chance—to recover. From
the start, Bob said he would fool
them and app`arently he is Winning
out.
The operation has not relieved the
almost complete paralysis which has
extended from Bob'8 neck to his
feet from the tinie of the accident.
Pressure on the spinal cord, however, has been greatly relieved, and

A change in the editorship of

THE NEWS-LETTER took place last
week, when J. Saulsbury Short, '15,
tendered his resignation from the
Board and Edmund M. Spieker,
'16, was elected from the staff of
associate editors to the position of
editor-in-chief.
.v1 r. Short, who succeeded Alexander K. Barton as editor-in-chief,
is also editor of the Hullabaloo, and
it was because of the great amount
of time required in getting. up the
year book that he was led to give
up the weekly. His resignation was
read at the meeting of the staff on
Monday, and takes effect with this
issue. On Thursday night, at a
meeting of the entire Board, Dorsey
Richardson moved that Mr. Spieker
be elected unanimously to the position. and the motion was carried.
The new editor-in-chief is a member of the junior class and is director of the Glee Club. 1-le has been
a member of the editorial staff since
his sophomore year, and during that
time, in addition to his regular duties, has served as managing editor,
directing the publication of several
issues of the paper. He has been
one of the most active editors of
THE NEWS-LETTER, and was considered eminently qualified to direct
its affairs during the remainder of
this year and during his senior
year. He is the son of Dr. Edward
IT. Spieker, associate professor of
Greek and Latin.
At Thursday's meeting of the
Board the'question of electing several new editors was discussed, and
it was decided to choose from
among- the twenty-five candidates
five whose work stood highest in
quantity and quality. The staff,
however, wishes .it known that the
selection of the five men does not
indicate that there are no more positions to be filled.
, Later in the year several more
men are to be selected from among
the men who are already candidates
in addition to those who have recently reported themselves as interested in- the activity. The Board
will probably elect five more editors
at the end of this academic year or
next October, and invites all undergraduates to take part in the competition for the positions. Candidates should speak with Mr. Spieker
or with any other member of the
I>oard.

The Musical Clubs will open their
season on February 3 with a concert at the Phipps Phychiatric Clinic
of the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The remainder of the concerts
which have been definitely settled
upon will be given as follows:
February 5—Western Maryland
College, Westminster, Md.
February 6—Cumberland, Md.
February 9—McCoy Hall (concert and dance).
February 16—Odd Fellows' Hall,
Baltimore.
The Instrumental Club and the
quartet will give selections at the
coming interclass debate, and several important town concerts will be
held later in thes season, with two
more trips, arrangements for which
have not yet been completed.
Much interest has been shown by
the candidates for both teams and
the work of the past week was
marked by great improvement. The
clubs are doing better work than
Hopkins musical organizations have
done in a long time, and bid fair to
have a most successful season. The
McCoy Hall concert, coming as it
does directly following the Western
Maryland trip, should be better than
usual in every particular, and other
town engagements promise to do
much toward establishing a good
reputation for the clubs.
Although they are starting out
on the season one month later than
the usual time, the leaders of the
teams are determined to make up
for lost time by doing as well as
possible at a large number of concerts, and thus to put the organization on .a firm footing for future
years. At present things look as if
the desired 'result will be accomplished.

DR. DUNNING A CLEVER SPEAKER

KAPPA ALPHA RE1NAUGURATED

Lecturer Under the Schouler Foundation
is Noted as Student and Wit- To
Talk on Political Theory.

Old Hopkins Fraternity Had Nine Initiates at Formal Reorganization Meeting—Three Faculty Members.

Prof. William A. Dunning, of
Columbia University, the lecturer
under the James Schouler Foundation this year, will give a series of
four addresses—the first one taking
place at 5 o'clock on Monday, January 25, in McCoy Hall.
The general subject of the whole
course will be "Early Phases of
Nineteenth Century Political Theory." This, while rather a philosophical field, is one of Dr. Dunning's specialties, and, as he has the
reputation for being one of the cleverest and most amusing talkers in
university circles, there seems little
ground for fear the lectures will be
too dry to be popular. In the words
of Dr. Schouler, under whose foundation the Columbia professor will
speak, he is "a keen investigator,
but somewhat inclining to levity in
his conclusions."
Dr. Dunning has been connected
with Columbia during his whole
teaching life and has trained many
prominent historical students. He
is author of a number of authoritative books on political philosophy
and on the Civil War and Reconstruction, the latter being his historical hobby. He is a frequent
contributor to the leading magazines, ranking high among political
commentators. From 1894 to 1903,
Dr. Dunning was managing editor
of the American Political Science
Quarterly, and in 1913 was president of the American Historical Association. He is at present Leiber
professor of history and political
philosophy in Columbia.
The lectures under the Schouler
Foundation in past years have numbered the most distinguished political students of the nation: President Lowell, of Harvard; Dr. John
Bassett Moore, of Columbia; former Assistant Secretary of State,
James Schouler; Dr. Josef Redlich,
the distinguished Austrian economist; and Dr. Charles Francis Adams, the historian of the Civil War,
who spoke here last year to audiences that filled McCoy Hall to the
doors.
The dates and subjects of Dr.
Dunning's course are as follows:
Monday, January 25—"Conservative and Reactionary Doctrine."
Tuesday, January 26— "British
Utilitarianism."
Monday, February I—"The Philosophy of Constitutionalism."
Tuesday, February —"The Philosophy of Nationalism."

Alpha Lambda Chapter, Kappa
Alpha Fraternity, resumed active
existence at Johns Hopkins with a
formal reinauguration at the Hotel
Rennert, Saturday evening, January 16. This chapter was founded
at Hopkins in 1891, but since 1910,
though remaining chartered, has
been in abeyance.
The reinduction was under the
auspices of the Baltimore Alumni
Chapter and the direction of William T. Biedler, province commander. Dr. S. Z. Ammen, one of the
founders of the order at Washington and Lee University in 1865, was
present at the initiation, as were
representatives of the Washington
alumni and of the Delaware, George
Washington, Randolph Macon,
West Virginia and Virginia chapters. The original charter was presented to the newly-organized chapter by Mr. James L. Bost, president
of the Washington Alumni Chapter,
and a Hopkins initiate.
The initiates were: Linn H. Enslow (G.), William S. Fitzgerald
(G.), J. Ernst Warrener (M.), W.
Brown Baxley, Edward E. Kaiser,
William Kendall, Jr., Thomas S.
Poole, Harold E. Scarborough and
John S. Watson. But one member
of the former chapter remains at
the University (A. L. Hammond,
'14). Kappa Alpha is represented
at the Medical School by a number of men, and in the faculty by
Professors J. B. Watson, J. H.
Latane and J. C. W. Frazer.

Y. M.C. A. MEETINGS LAST WEEK

The evangelistic meetings, held
this week under the auspices of the
University Young Men's Christian
Association, were attended by very
appreciative audiences.
On Wednesday, Mr. E. C. Mercer, better known as "Ted," delivered an address pleading against
selfishness, which he pointed out
was absolutely non-Christian. Mr.
Mercer gave several instances of
the results of one's interest being
self-centered.'There were about
one hundred and twenty-five men
present. A light lunch was served
before the meeting.
After a light lunch at the Thursday noon hour, about one hundred
and ten men heard Dr. Ray Palmer
speak on "Be Sure Your Sins Will
Find You Out." It was a very
strong and forceful talk illustrated
by many interesting and actual instances.
At 5 o'clock on Thursday, Mr.
Weston G. Bruner was the speaker.
On Friday, at noon, Mr. Mercer
delivered his second and closing address of the series. In his usual
forceful manner he told his audience of about ninety why he was
a Christian. He pointed out that

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 25, 1915.

PROF. DENNISON TELLS OF
CAESAR'S BATTLES IN FRANCE

SWIMMERS MAY GET DUAL MEET
WITH PRINCETON TIGERS

"The Military Operations of
Julius Caesar in France and Belgium in Their Relation to the Present European War," was the subject of an address last Friday, delivered by Prof. Walter Dennison
of Swarthmore College, who was
annual professor at the American
School of Classical Studies in
Rome, 1908-09, and is secretary of
the Archaeological Institute of Philadelphia.
After a short introduction by
Mr. James Teakle Dennis, the new
president of the Archaeological Institute of Baltimore, Professor Dennison began by pointing out that the
battlefields of today are upon the
scene of many of the great European conflicts of the past. Upon
this same field the Celts and Teutons struggled for the fertile valley
of the Rhine twenty centuries ago.
From Caesar's first conflict with
the Helvetii in 58 B. C., Dr. Dennison traced his campaign up the
Rhine, where, near Strassburg he
met and defeated Ariovistus; thence
crossing the Vosges Mountains, he
told how Caesar overcame the Belgian host at the Aisne, and the
Nervii at Manberge.
Dr. Dennison also showed excellent views of Alesia, where in 52
B. C. the Gaulic army under Vercingetorix was shut up and starved
into submission. Here Napoleon
III erected a massive statue to the
first French national hero, and in
the nearby town of Alise is one of
the best collections of barbarian
relics now existing.
He also showed pictures of Roman
artillery and of Roman trenches discovered near this "graveyard of
the Gallic people."
By the aid of excellent illustrations Caesar's campaigns were reenacted, and his "Commentaries"
vivified in a manner which is rarely
accomplished by the average teacher.

The independent swimming team
has added another meet to its already pretentious schedule. Princeton has been practically closed for a
meet at the Baltimore Athletic Club
on Saturday evening, March 13.
While several details have yet to be
arranged in regard to this contest,
there seems to be every assurance
that it will be definitely arranged.
The Princeton Alumni Association
of Baltimore is eager to have the
Tigers appear in the city, and as the
Association's annual banquet is
scheduled to take place the same
night as the meet, hearty support
from that quarter is a certainty.
The swimmers are practicing
regularly, and are in good shape.
They will open their season next
Saturday in a practice meet with
City College in the Young Men's
Christian Association pool: Three
practices are held weekly: Tuesday
afternoon, Wednesday night and
Saturday morning.
DR. GUTTMACHER, DECEASED,
WAS A GRADUATE OF HOPKINS

The Rev. Dr. Adolf Guttmacher,
the noted Baltimore rabbi, who died
suddenly on January 17, was an
alumnus of the Johns Hopkins University.
Dr. Guttmacher received the degree of doctor of philosophy from
Hopkins in 19oo, at the same time
that Dr. William Rosenau took his
degree. His work while at this college was confined mainly to the
semitic graduate department.
Dr. Guttmacher was one of the
ablest and most esteemed rabbis of
the city. He had charge of the
Madison Avenue Temple from 1891
to 19oo, and by his conscientious
work developed that congregation
from a small body to one of more
than a thousand members.
